content: Taiwanese, Hokkien and Teochew dish of eggs and oysters The **oyster omelette** or **oyster cake[a]**, also known as **o-a-tsian** ([Hokkien](/wiki/Hokkien) [Chinese](/wiki/Traditional_Chinese_characters): 蚵仔煎; [Pe̍h-ōe-jī](/wiki/Pe%CC%8Dh-%C5%8De-j%C4%AB): *ô-á-chian*), **o-chien** ([Hokkien](/wiki/Hokkien) [Chinese](/wiki/Traditional_Chinese_characters): 蚵煎; [Pe̍h-ōe-jī](/wiki/Pe%CC%8Dh-%C5%8De-j%C4%AB): *ô-chian*) or **orh luak** ([Teochew](/wiki/Teochew_Min) [traditional Chinese](/wiki/Traditional_Chinese_characters): 蠔烙; [simplified Chinese](/wiki/Simplified_Chinese_characters): 蚝烙; [Peng'im](/wiki/Peng%27im): *o5 luah4*), is a dish of [Southern Min](/wiki/Southern_Min) ([Hokkien](/wiki/Hoklo_people) and [Teochew](/wiki/Teochew_people)) origin that is renowned for its savory flavor in its native [Minnan region](/wiki/Minnan_region) and [Chaoshan](/wiki/Chaoshan), along with [Taiwan](/wiki/Taiwan) and many parts of Southeast Asia, such as [Indonesia](/wiki/Indonesia), [Philippines](/wiki/Philippines), [Thailand](/wiki/Thailand), [Malaysia](/wiki/Malaysia) or [Singapore](/wiki/Singapore), due to the influence of the Hokkien and Teochew diaspora. ## Ingredients The dish consists of an [omelette](/wiki/Omelette) with a filling primarily composed of small [Pacific oysters](/wiki/Pacific_oyster). Starch (typically sweet potato starch) is mixed into the egg batter, giving the resulting egg wrap a thicker consistency. Pork lard is often used to fry the resulting omelet. Depending on regional variations, a savory sauce may then be poured on top of the omelette for added taste.[*citation needed*] Spicy or chili sauce mixed with lime juice is often added to provide an intense kick. Shrimp can sometimes be substituted in place of oysters; in this case, it is called shrimp omelette (蝦仁煎). ## Names In different [Chinese languages](/wiki/Chinese_language), the "oyster omelette" is known by various names in different Chinese geographical regions. classified into two categories, namely, Hokkien-style omelettes and Teochew-style omelettes. The former is popular in [Minnan](/wiki/Minnan_region) and [Taiwan](/wiki/Taiwan), while latter is the usual style seen in [Hong Kong](/wiki/Hong_Kong) and [Chaoshan](/wiki/Chaoshan) areas. The two styles of oyster omelettes are also different in terms of key ingredients used. The former uses chicken eggs and a mixture of sweet potato flour, tapioca flour and/or cornstarch as the batter; the latter uses duck eggs and sweet potato flour The cooking processes are slightly different too, as the Hokkien ones are deep-fried, while Teochew-style ones are usually pan-fried. ## Thailand In Thailand known as *hoi thot* ([Thai](/wiki/Thai_language): หอยทอด; lit: "fried shellfish"), it was adapted to [mussel](/wiki/Perna_viridis) omelettes (*hoi malaeng phu thot*, [Thai](/wiki/Thai_language): หอยแมลงภู่ทอด), though the original oyster version (*hot nang rom thot*, [Thai](/wiki/Thai_language): หอยนางรมทอด) also popular but more expensive. In Bangkok, notable areas for oyster omelettes include [Talat Wang Lang](/wiki/Talat_Wang_Lang) near [Siriraj Hospital](/wiki/Siriraj_Hospital) and Wang Lang (Siriraj) Pier in [Bangkok Noi](/wiki/Bangkok_Noi) where there are two restaurants, [Yaowarat](/wiki/Yaowarat) [neighborhood](/wiki/Bangkok%27s_Chinatown), where there is one [Michelin](/wiki/Michelin_Guide)-[Bib Gourmand](/wiki/Bib_Gourmand) restaurant with [Charoen Krung](/wiki/Charoen_Krung) neighborhood in [Bang Rak](/wiki/Bang_Rak), among others. In 2017, the World Street Food Congress announced that oyster omelette is one of the three most notable [street foods](/wiki/Street_food) among the [street foods of Thailand](/wiki/Street_food_of_Thailand). ## Gallery - Food portal - [Night markets in Taiwan](/wiki/Night_markets_in_Taiwan) - [Hangtown fry](/wiki/Hangtown_fry) - [Pajeon](/wiki/Pajeon) - [List of Chinese dishes](/wiki/List_of_Chinese_dishes) - [List of egg dishes](/wiki/List_of_egg_dishes) - [List of seafood dishes](/wiki/List_of_seafood_dishes) ## Notes
